item.title: Router Help!
item.dc:creator: @hellzowner hellzowner
item.description:
@hellzowner wrote:

you can figure out how too log onto your router by going too run then type cmd then in command prompt type ipconfig and write down your default gateway and then type it into the internet explorer and then boom

Read full topic

item.title: Router Help!
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Which IP address are you port forwarding to? You need to port forward to your computer’s IP address on your network at home - not your IP address on the internet; they’re two very different numbers in most cases.

To find the IP address you need to port forward to, go to Start > run > type ‘cmd’ without the quotation marks, then when command prompt comes up type ‘ipconfig’, once again without any quotation marks.

The number to the right of IP address is the number you need to port forward to. Then you just need to enable connections using TCP through your firewall to that port.

EDIT: In case your confused, the IPs for computers on the local network usually look something like: 192.168.1.10 - that’s my computer’s IP, and my other computer’s is 192.168.1.11 - Our router is 192.168.1.1, so you should see the resemblance.

Read full topic
